question.text: what was the prison called in the green mile ?

1. En 1935, Paul supervise des officiers à la prison de Cold Mountain.
2. Paul souffre d'une grave infection de la vessie.
3. John Coffey est un homme noir physiquement imposant mais mentalement déficient.
4. John Coffey est condamné à mort pour le viol et le meurtre de deux filles blanches.
5. Arlen Bitterbuck est un Amérindien accusé de meurtre.
6. Arlen Bitterbuck est le premier à être exécuté.
7. Percy Wetmore montre une tendance sadique sévère.
8. Percy est le neveu de la Première Dame de Louisiane.
9. Percy est particulièrement abusif envers l'inmate Eduard Delacroix.
10. Percy casse les doigts de Delacroix avec sa matraque.
11. Percy marche sur une souris de compagnie nommée Mr. Jingles.
12. Percy appelle Delacroix par une insulte homophobe.
13. Percy sabote l'exécution de Delacroix en ne mouillant pas l'éponge.
14. Delacroix meurt en hurlant de douleur.

prompt.user: In 1935, Paul supervises officers Brutus Howell, Dean Stanton, Harry Terwilliger, and Percy Wetmore at Cold Mountain Penitentiary. Paul is suffering from a severe bladder infection and receives John Coffey, a physically imposing but mentally challenged black man, into his custody. John had been sentenced to death after being convicted of raping and murdering two white girls. One of the other inmates is a Native-American named Arlen Bitterbuck, who is charged with murder and is the first to be executed. Percy demonstrates a severe sadistic streak, but, as the nephew of Louisiana's First Lady, he is beyond reproach. He is particularly abusive with inmate Eduard Delacroix; he breaks Del's fingers with his baton, steps on a pet mouse named Mr. Jingles, which Del had adopted, repeatedly calls him by a gay slur, and ultimately sabotages his execution by failing to soak the sponge used to conduct electricity to Del's head; Del dies screaming in pain.

question.text: what is the widest highway in north america ?

llm_answer.text:

2. It is also known as the Macdonald–Cartier Freeway.
3. It is colloquially called the four-oh-one.
4. Highway 401 is a controlled-access highway.
5. It is part of the 400-series highways in Ontario.
6. The highway stretches 828.0 kilometres.
7. It runs from Windsor to the Ontario–Quebec border.
8. The section through Toronto is North America's busiest highway.
9. It is one of the widest highways in North America.
10. Highway 401 forms part of the Quebec City–Windsor Corridor.
11. Over half of Canada's population resides along this corridor.
12. It is a Core Route in the National Highway System of Canada.
13. The Ministry of Transportation of Ontario maintains the route.
14. The Ontario Provincial Police patrol the highway.
15. The speed limit is 100 km/h unless posted otherwise.

prompt.user: King's Highway 401, commonly referred to as Highway 401 and also known by its official name as the Macdonald–Cartier Freeway or colloquially as the four-oh-one,[3] is a controlled-access400-series highway in the Canadian province of Ontario. It stretches 828.0 kilometres (514.5 mi) from Windsor in the west to the Ontario–Quebec border in the east. The part of Highway 401 that passes through Toronto is North America's busiest highway,[4][5] and one of the widest.[6][7] Together with Quebec Autoroute 20, it forms the road transportation backbone of the Quebec City–Windsor Corridor, along which over half of Canada's population resides and is also a Core Route in the National Highway System of Canada. The route is maintained by the Ministry of Transportation of Ontario (MTO) and patrolled by the Ontario Provincial Police. The speed limit is 100 km/h (62 mph) throughout its length, unless posted otherwise.

question.text: what makes the center of an atom stable ?

llm_answer.text:
1. Les électrons dans un atome sont attirés par les protons dans le noyau.
2. Cette attraction est due à la force électromagnétique.
3. La force électromagnétique lie les électrons dans un puits de potentiel électrostatique.
4. Le noyau est plus petit que le puits de potentiel électrostatique.
5. Une source d'énergie externe est nécessaire pour qu'un électron s'échappe.
6. Plus un électron est proche du noyau, plus la force attractive est grande.
7. Les électrons proches du centre du puits de potentiel nécessitent plus d'énergie pour s'échapper.
8. Les électrons plus éloignés du noyau nécessitent moins d'énergie pour s'échapper.

Hence electrons bound near the center of the potential well require more energy to escape than those at greater separations.

question.text: when would the quantity of dna double when growing cells ?

llm_answer.text:
1. Le cycle cellulaire comporte quatre phases principales.
2. La première phase est appelée phase G1.
3. La phase G1 est marquée par la synthèse d'enzymes nécessaires à la réplication de l'ADN.
4. La deuxième phase du cycle cellulaire est la phase S.
5. La phase S est le moment où la réplication de l'ADN produit deux ensembles identiques de chromosomes.
6. La troisième phase est la phase G2.
7. La phase G2 implique une synthèse protéique significative.
8. La production de microtubules se produit principalement pendant la phase G2.
9. La quatrième phase est la phase M.
10. La phase M consiste en la division nucléaire et cytoplasmique.
11. La division nucléaire est appelée caryocinèse.
12. La division cytoplasmique est appelée cytocinèse.
13. La phase M aboutit à la formation d'une nouvelle membrane cellulaire.
14. La phase M est la division physique des cellules mère et fille.
15. La phase M est subdivisée en plusieurs phases distinctes.
16. Les phases de la phase M sont prophase, prométaphase, métaphase, anaphase et télophase.
17. La cytocinèse suit la télophase.

prompt.user: The process of cell division, called cell cycle, has four major parts called phases. The first part, called G1 phase is marked by synthesis of various enzymes that are required for DNA replication. The second part of the cell cycle is the S phase, where DNA replication produces two identical sets of chromosomes. The third part is the G2 phase in which a significant protein synthesis occurs, mainly involving the production of microtubules that are required during the process of division, called mitosis. The fourth phase, M phase, consists of nuclear division (karyokinesis) and cytoplasmic division (cytokinesis), accompanied by the formation of a new cell membrane. This is the physical division of 'mother' and 'daughter' cells. The M phase has been broken down into several distinct phases, sequentially known as prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase leading to cytokinesis.

question.text: who determined the mass to charge ratio of an electron ?

llm_answer.text:
1. In the 19th century, the mass-to-charge ratios of some ions were measured by electrochemical methods.
2. In 1897, J. J. Thomson first measured the mass-to-charge ratio of the electron.
3. Thomson showed that the electron was a particle with a mass and a charge.
4. The mass-to-charge ratio of the electron was much smaller than that of the hydrogen ion H+.
5. In 1898, Wilhelm Wien separated ions according to their mass-to-charge ratio.
6. Wien used an ion optical device with superimposed electric and magnetic fields.
7. In 1901, Walter Kaufman measured the increase of electromagnetic mass of fast electrons.
8. This increase is known as relativistic mass increase in modern terms.
9. In 1913, Thomson measured the mass-to-charge ratio of ions with a parabola spectrograph.
10. An instrument that measures the mass-to-charge ratio of charged particles is called a mass spectrometer.

prompt.user: In the 19th century, the mass-to-charge ratios of some ions were measured by electrochemical methods. In 1897, the mass-to-charge ratio of the electron was first measured by J. J. Thomson. [6] By doing this, he showed that the electron was in fact a particle with a mass and a charge, and that its mass-to-charge ratio was much smaller than that of the hydrogen ion H+. In 1898, Wilhelm Wien separated ions (canal rays) according to their mass-to-charge ratio with an ion optical device with superimposed electric and magnetic fields (Wien filter). In 1901 Walter Kaufman measured the increase of electromagnetic mass of fast electrons (Kaufmann–Bucherer–Neumann experiments), or relativistic mass increase in modern terms. In 1913, Thomson measured the mass-to-charge ratio of ions with an instrument he called a parabola spectrograph.[7] Today, an instrument that measures the mass-to-charge ratio of charged particles is called a mass spectrometer.

question.text: when did the olympics first allow professional athletes ?

llm_answer.text:
1. Une dispute a eu lieu avant les Jeux olympiques d'hiver de 1984.
2. La dispute concernait la définition d'un joueur professionnel.
3. Le CIO avait adopté une règle concernant les joueurs ayant signé un contrat NHL.
4. Les joueurs ayant joué moins de dix matchs NHL étaient éligibles selon le CIO.
5. Le Comité olympique des États-Unis considérait tout joueur sous contrat NHL comme professionnel.
6. Le Comité olympique des États-Unis jugeait ces joueurs inéligibles.
7. Le CIO a tenu une réunion d'urgence sur cette question.
8. Le CIO a décidé que les joueurs sous contrat NHL étaient éligibles s'ils n'avaient pas joué de matchs NHL.
9. Cinq joueurs sur les listes olympiques sont devenus inéligibles.
10. Ces joueurs inéligibles comprenaient un Autrichien, deux Italiens et deux Canadiens.
11. Les joueurs ayant joué dans d'autres ligues professionnelles pouvaient jouer.
12. Alan Eagleson a déclaré que la règle ne s'appliquait qu'à la NHL.
13. Les joueurs sous contrat dans les ligues européennes étaient considérés comme amateurs.
14. Murray Costello a suggéré un possible retrait du Canada.
15. En 1986, le CIO a voté pour permettre à tous les athlètes de participer aux Jeux olympiques.
16. Les fédérations sportives individuelles pouvaient décider d'autoriser les professionnels.

prompt.user: Before the 1984 Winter Olympics, a dispute formed over what made a player a professional. The IOC had adopted a rule that made any player who had signed an NHL contract but played less than ten games in the league eligible. However, the United States Olympic Committee maintained that any player contracted with an NHL team was a professional and therefore not eligible to play. The IOC held an emergency meeting that ruled NHL-contracted players were eligible, as long as they had not played in any NHL games. This made five players on Olympic rosters—one Austrian, two Italians and two Canadians—ineligible. Players who had played in other professional leagues—such as the World Hockey Association—were allowed to play. Canadian hockey official Alan Eagleson stated that the rule was only applied to the NHL and that professionally contracted players in European leagues were still considered amateurs. Murray Costello of the CAHA suggested that a Canadian withdrawal was possible. In 1986, the IOC voted to allow all athletes to compete in Olympic Games starting in 1988, but let the individual sport federations decide if they wanted to allow professionals.

However, the United States Olympic Committee maintained that any player contracted with an NHL team was a professional and therefore not eligible to play (5, 6). The IOC held an emergency meeting (7) that ruled NHL-contracted players were eligible, as long as they had not played in any NHL games (8). This made five players on Olympic rosters—one Austrian, two Italians and two Canadians—ineligible (9, 10). Players who had played in other professional leagues—such as the World Hockey Association—were allowed to play (11). Canadian hockey official Alan Eagleson stated that the rule was only applied to the NHL (12) and that professionally contracted players in European leagues were still considered amateurs (13). Murray Costello of the CAHA suggested that a Canadian withdrawal was possible (14). In 1986, the IOC voted to allow all athletes to compete in Olympic Games starting in 1988, but let the individual sport federations decide if they wanted to allow professionals (15, 16).

question.text: where does water come from in cell respiration ?

llm_answer.text:
1. Oxidative phosphorylation occurs in the mitochondrial cristae in eukaryotes.
2. The electron transport chain is part of oxidative phosphorylation.
3. The electron transport chain establishes a proton gradient across the inner membrane.
4. The proton gradient is also known as chemiosmotic potential.
5. NADH from the Krebs cycle is oxidized in the electron transport chain.
6. ATP is synthesized by the ATP synthase enzyme.
7. The chemiosmotic gradient drives the phosphorylation of ADP.
8. Electrons are transferred to exogenous oxygen.
9. Water is formed with the addition of two protons.

ATP is synthesized by the ATP synthase enzyme when the chemiosmotic gradient is used to drive the phosphorylation of ADP. The electrons are finally transferred to exogenous oxygen and, with the addition of two protons, water is formed.
